content.description: Shares a start with Cat Arete. Use face crimps and undercling to gain crimp; arete is off. Then move left to a flat crimp and up through the left side of v-notch to a top out. Crux comes high.
An extension of Elias where one starts matched on the prominent undercling, very scrunched up, and then moves into the diagonal crimp.
Follow the path of the arete while staying on the face to the right. Step up to the ledge, then use the comfortable slopers and jugs to pull your way up to the top!
content.location: On the left face of the boulder, between the arete and crack.

content.description:
Climb The Dawg to the crimps beneath the "big move to the top" and instead of throwing, continue to move out right on more crimps, exiting via the notch (where the horizontal top lip suddenly angles up to the peak of the arête). 

 The book gives this V6 although some may find it easier than The Dawg (book = V5).

Start with hands on holds next to the "6"s from the beta photo for Cat Rock. Bring your right hand up to the crimp (at the top of the V in the photo), and then toss for the sloping shelf. Gain the positive holds above and top out. Fun one move wonder.
content.protection: Crux is low, but probably want pad for the top out.

content.description:
Haven't done this one yet, so going by the guidebook description. This is also known as The Pinch Problem. 

  Start with your left hand on a small, left-facing, lieback hold, which is nearly 6' above the ground and 5' right of the obtuse arete at the left end. Your right hand goes on a crimp to the right. The first move is to place the right hand on the pinch hold at the short and very rightmost vertical seam. Take the direct line to the lowest top-out without using the sloping shelf to the left.

A very tough eliminate of Scratching Post. Start matched on a diagonal crimp. Gain mostly-broken LH epoxy hold, and then plant your foot to go to an almost nonexistent sloper. The good crimp used on Scratching Post is off. Top out direct. Nearly impossible in summer.The almost nonexistent epoxy hold used to exist. Was graded V9 when it existed, currently hovering between 9/10 and 10.

Start with your right hand on the pinch high up and your left hand on the heavily chalked dish. Follow the line of crimps up and a trending right, then make a large move to the crimp at the lip (there may be intermediates that I skipped) and top out.
content.location: Look for the knee-height "cave" beneath and slightly right of the bush that grows atop Felix/Obtuse Arête

content.description: climb the corner to the top.   top out to the right.
content.protection: a pad is good, but spotter(s) better for this one, landing is pretty sloped.
content.location: just right of the arete on the right side of cat rock.   one can also go up the face to the right, pad and spotter(s) def necessary there.

content.description: Climb the finger crack straight up and top out.

You can either start by straddling the arete with hands on either side, or on the left face left with your right hand on the arete and heel hook and bump you right side up, while making use of crimps for your left. Lots of fun.
content.protection: Probably want a pad, its tall.
content.location: The rightmost arete on the rock.

content.description: Cat Rock faces southwest, and so it's dark rock receives plenty of sun. Since it is also fairly well protected from wind, head here when its cold out. You'll also want to bring a crashpad...one of the easier problems here (Cat Corner) has a pretty bad landing and many of the others top out at about 15 ft.
